title: Sedlec Ossuary
text:
The Sedlec Ossuary (; ) is a <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> <a href="chapel">chapel</a>, located beneath the Cemetery Church of All Saints (Czech: "Hřbitovní kostel Všech Svatých"), part of the former <a href="Sedlec%20Abbey">Sedlec Abbey</a> in Sedlec, a suburb of <a href="Kutn%C3%A1%20Hora">Kutná Hora</a> in the <a href="Czech%20Republic">Czech Republic</a>. The <a href="ossuary">ossuary</a> is estimated to contain the <a href="skeletons">skeletons</a> of between 40,000 and 70,000 people, whose bones have, in many cases, been artistically arranged to form decorations and furnishings for the chapel. The ossuary is among the most visited <a href="tourist%20attraction">tourist attraction</a>s of the Czech Republic, attracting over 200,000 visitors annually.
Four bell-shaped mounds occupy the corners of the chapel. A <a href="chandelier">chandelier</a> of bones, which contains at least one of every bone in the human body, hangs from the center of the nave with garlands of <a href="human%20skull">skull</a>s draping the vault. Other works include piers and <a href="monstrance">monstrance</a>s flanking the <a href="altar">altar</a>, a <a href="coat%20of%20arms">coat of arms</a> of the <a href="House%20of%20Schwarzenberg">House of Schwarzenberg</a>, and the signature of <a href="Franti%C5%A1ek%20Rint">František Rint</a>, also executed in bone, on the wall near the entrance.
Along with Sedlec Abbey and the rest of the <a href="Kutn%C3%A1%20Hora">Kutná Hora</a> city centre, it was listed as a <a href="UNESCO%20World%20Heritage%20Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a> in 1995, because of its unique <a href="Baroque%20architecture">Baroque architecture</a>.
History.
In 1278, Henry, the <a href="abbot">abbot</a> of the <a href="Cistercian">Cistercian</a> <a href="monastery">monastery</a> in Sedlec, was sent to the <a href="Holy%20Land">Holy Land</a> by King <a href="Otakar%20II%20of%20Bohemia">Otakar II of Bohemia</a>. He returned with a small amount of earth he had removed from <a href="Golgotha">Golgotha</a> and sprinkled it over the abbey <a href="cemetery">cemetery</a>. The word of this pious act soon spread and the cemetery in Sedlec became a desirable <a href="burial">burial</a> site throughout <a href="Central%20Europe">Central Europe</a>.
In the mid 14th century, during the <a href="Black%20Death">Black Death</a>, and after the <a href="Hussite%20Wars">Hussite Wars</a> in the early 15th century, many thousands were buried in the abbey cemetery, so it had to be greatly enlarged.
Around 1400, a <a href="Gothic%20architecture">Gothic</a> church was built in the center of the cemetery with a <a href="Vault%20%28architecture%29">vaulted</a> upper level and a lower chapel to be used as an <a href="ossuary">ossuary</a> for the mass graves unearthed during construction, or simply slated for demolition to make room for new burials.
After 1511, the task of <a href="exhumation">exhuming</a> skeletons and stacking their bones in the chapel was given to a half-<a href="blindness">blind</a> <a href="monk">monk</a> of the order.
Between 1703 and 1710, a new entrance was constructed to support the front wall, which was leaning outward, and the upper chapel was rebuilt. This work, in the Czech <a href="Baroque%20architecture">Baroque</a> style, was designed by <a href="Jan%20Santini%20Aichel">Jan Santini Aichel</a>.
In 1870, <a href="Franti%C5%A1ek%20Rint">František Rint</a>, a woodcarver, was employed by the <a href="House%20of%20Schwarzenberg">Schwarzenberg</a> family to put the bone heaps into order, yielding a <a href="macabre">macabre</a> result. The signature of Rint, also executed in bone, appears on the wall near the entrance to the chapel.
In media.
In 1970, the centenary of Rint's contributions, Czech filmmaker <a href="Jan%20%C5%A0vankmajer">Jan Švankmajer</a> was commissioned to document the ossuary. The result was a 10-minute-long frantic-cut film of skeletal images overdubbed with an actual tour-guide's neutral voice narration. This version was initially banned by the Czech Communist authorities for alleged <a href="subversion">subversion</a>, and the soundtrack was replaced by a brief spoken introduction and a <a href="jazz">jazz</a> arrangement by <a href="Zden%C4%9Bk%20Li%C5%A1ka">Zdeněk Liška</a> of the <a href="poem">poem</a> "Comment dessiner le portrait d'un oiseau" ("How to Draw the Portrait of a Bird") by <a href="Jacques%20Pr%C3%A9vert">Jacques Prévert</a>. Since the <a href="Velvet%20Revolution">Velvet Revolution</a>, the original tour guide soundtrack has been made available.
In the documentary "<a href="Long%20Way%20Round">Long Way Round</a>", <a href="Ewan%20McGregor">Ewan McGregor</a> and <a href="Charley%20Boorman">Charley Boorman</a> stop to see this church. <a href="Dan%20Cruickshank">Dan Cruickshank</a> also views the church in his "<a href="Dan%20Cruickshank%27s%20Adventures%20in%20Architecture">Adventures in Architecture</a>".
The ossuary is a major plot device in the <a href="John%20Connolly%20%28author%29">John Connolly</a> novel "The Black Angel".
The ossuary is used as a location for the <a href="Dungeons%20%26amp%3B%20Dragons%20%28film%20series%29">"Dungeons & Dragons" movie</a> and the movie "<a href="Blood%20%26amp%3B%20Chocolate%20%28film%29">Blood & Chocolate</a>".
The ossuary was featured in "<a href="Ripley%27s%20Believe%20it%20or%20Not">Ripley's Believe it or Not</a>" and is described by <a href="Cara%20Seymour">Cara Seymour</a> in the final scene of the film "<a href="Adaptation%20%28film%29">Adaptation</a>".
The ossuary influenced Dr. Satan's lair in the <a href="Rob%20Zombie">Rob Zombie</a> film "<a href="House%20of%201000%20Corpses">House of 1000 Corpses</a>".
The ossuary appeared on two versions of "<a href="The%20Amazing%20Race">The Amazing Race</a>": "<a href="The%20Amazing%20Race%20Australia%201">The Amazing Race Australia 1</a>" and "<a href="HaMerotz%20LaMillion%202">HaMerotz LaMillion 2</a>".
